response: * Alexander Craig Gibson (1813–1874), folklorist around Coniston, Cumbria

In 1830, the "Manager's house" was built. The building was used by the clerk and the manager when he visited. The rooms inside housed storage, a bedroom, a kitchen and an office/boardroom.History given on displays inside the youth hostel in 2016 From 1849 to 1857 the mines employed Alexander Craig Gibson as their surgeon. Gibson was noted for his books on local folklore.Albert Nicholson, ‘Gibson, Alexander Craig (1813–1874)’, rev. Angus J. L. Winchester, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004 accessed 27 Dec 2016

Already in the 19th century, Alexander Craig Gibson called it "an exquisite and unique specimen of a style of bridge all but extinct"; a century later, Alfred Wainwright called it "the most picturesque footbridge in Lakeland, a slender arch constructed of slate from the quarries and built to give the quarrymen a shorter access from their homes".
